title: Judge halts 8 executions in Arkansas
text:
Judge halts 8 executions in Arkansas State trying to resume executions after 10 years Published 4:06 PM EDT Oct 09, 2015 Photos 
iStock/oneword 
An Arkansas judge has halted the executions of eight death row inmates as lethal injection practices there are challenged, The Associated Press reported Friday. 
Oklahoma will delay any further executions as officials investigate how the wrong drug may have been used in the execution of Charles Warner back in January. 
In a statement Thursday, Gov. Mary Fallin said the mix-up came to light after state officials... Inmates are challenging the state's new law allowing officials to withhold information identifying the manufacturers or sellers of the execution drugs. Arkansas is trying to put prisoners to death for the first time in a decade, AP reported. Friday's ruling was made by Pulaski County Circuit Court Judge Wendell Griffen. The new law would put inmates at risk of unconstitutional suffering during their executions since they couldn't vet the drugs' safety and effectiveness, a lawyer for the inmates in the lawsuit told the AP.
